full_text:
--- Page 1 ---

1
 
 
 
ST ATEMENT
 
OF
 
INTENT
 
NKWOR
 
JANE
 
CHINELO
 
 
I
 
aim
 
to
 
develop
 
reinforcement
 
learning
 
methods
 
that
 
learn
 
efficiently
 
from
 
sparse,
 
noisy ,
 
or
 
delayed
 
feedback
 
and
 
generalise
 
reliably
 
across
 
real-world
 
environments.
 
During
 
a
 
2018
 
university
 
strike,
 
I
 
enrolled
 
in
 
a
 
programming
 
school,
 
where
 
I
 
developed
 
a
 
deep
 
fascination
 
with
 
how
 
systems
 
represent
 
information,
 
make
 
decisions,
 
and
 
adapt
 
in
 
the
 
face
 
of
 
uncertainty .
 
These
 
questions
 
now
 
anchor
 
my
 
research
 
agenda
 
in
 
Reinforcement
 
Learning.
 
This
 
focus
 
matured
 
during
 
my
 
master ’s
 
dissertation,
 
Development
 
of
 
an
 
Autonomous
 
Agent
 
for
 
a
 
Number
 
Strategy
 
Game
 
Using
 
Deep
 
Q-Networks.
 
Motivated
 
by
 
an
 
interest
 
in
 
how
 
systems—biological
 
or
 
artificial—learn
 
under
 
uncertainty ,
 
I
 
developed
 
a
 
DQN-based
 
agent
 
augmented
 
with
 
Prioritised
 
Experience
 
Replay .
 
I
 
trained
 
and
 
evaluated
 
the
 
agent
 
across
 
hundreds
 
of
 
episodes,
 
comparing
 
its
 
performance
 
to
 
deterministic
 
baselines
 
such
 
as
 
Minimax
 
and
 
Reservoir
 
Sampling.
 
The
 
DQN
 
achieved
 
an
 
over
 
85%
 
success
 
rate
 
by
 
generalising
 
from
 
experience
 
rather
 
than
 
relying
 
on
 
exhaustive
 
computation
 
–
 
findings
 
I
 
have
 
documented
 
in
 
a
 
manuscript
 
currently
 
under
 
review
 
and
 
a
 
conference
 
paper
 
accepted
 
for
 
presentation
 
in
 
2025.
 
I
 
confronted
 
vanishing
 
rewards,
 
unstable
 
training
 
dynamics,
 
and
 
sensitivity
 
to
 
hyperparameters.
 
Addressing
 
these
 
challenges
 
required
 
designing
 
custom
 
reward-shaping
 
strategies,
 
adjusting
 
network
 
architectures,
 
and
 
experimenting
 
with
 
exploration
 
schedules
 
to
 
optimise
 
performance.
 
Moreover ,
 
the
 
project
 
revealed
 
deeper
 
limitations
 
with
 
standard
 
DQN
 
methods,
 
including
 
overestimation
 
bias,
 
poor
 
sample
 
efficiency ,
 
and
 
fragility
 
in
 
high-dimensional
 
settings.
 
These
 
gaps
 
highlight
 
a
 
central
 
challenge:
 
deploying
 
RL
 
agents
 
in
 
real-world
 
environments
 
requires
 
learning
 
from
 
imperfect
 
signals
 
(sparse
 
rewards,
 
delays),
 
adapting
 
across
 
diverse
 
contexts
 
(transfer
 
learning),
 
and
 
doing
 
so
 
safely
 
(robustness,
 

--- Page 2 ---

2
 
trustworthiness).
 
These
 
challenges
 
are
 
critical
 
for
 
deploying
 
autonomous
 
systems
 
in
 
high-stakes
 
domains
 
such
 
as
 
healthcare
 
robotics,
 
autonomous
 
vehicles,
 
and
 
human-robot
 
collaboration,
 
where
 
safety
 
failures
 
have
 
real
 
consequences.
 
My
 
doctoral
 
research
 
will
 
address
 
these
 
interconnected
 
challenges
 
through
 
principled
 
algorithmic
 
and
 
theoretical
 
inquiry .
 
Across
 
my
 
experiences
 
in
 
reinforcement
 
learning,
 
language
 
modelling,
 
and
 
human-centred
 
system
 
design,
 
I
 
have
 
come
 
to
 
appreciate
 
that
 
building
 
trustworthy
 
autonomous
 
systems
 
requires
 
more
 
than
 
algorithmic
 
sophistication.
 
RL
 
provides
 
me
 
with
 
the
 
tools
 
to
 
model
 
adaptive
 
decision-making.
 
My
 
interest
 
in
 
collaborating
 
with
 
faculty
 
like
 
Professor
 
Jaime
 
Fernández
 
Fisac
 
and
 
Professor
 
Chi
 
Jin
 
reflects
 
my
 
eagerness
 
to
 
contribute
 
to
 
Princeton's
 
vibrant
 
research
 
community
 
and
 
learn
 
from
 
their
 
expertise.
 
Princeton
 
University
 
offers
 
a
 
uniquely
 
strong
 
environment
 
for
 
advancing
 
my
 
research
 
goals
 
at
 
the
 
intersection
 
of
 
reinforcement
 
learning,
 
safety ,
 
and
 
autonomous
 
systems.
 
I
 
am
 
particularly
 
interested
 
in
 
working
 
with
 
Professor
 
Jaime
 
Fernández
 
Fisac,
 
whose
 
group
 
develops
 
theories
 
and
 
algorithms
 
that
 
enable
 
robots
 
to
 
ensure
 
safety
 
in
 
dynamic,
 
unpredictable
 
human
 
environments
 
actively .
 
Moreover ,
 
his
 
commitment
 
to
 
rigorous
 
safety
 
guarantees
 
that
 
people
 
can
 
understand
 
and
 
trust
 
these
 
systems
,
 
aligning
 
with
 
my
 
belief
 
that
 
deployable
 
autonomous
 
systems
 
must
 
offer
 
interpretable
 
safety
 
assurances,
 
particularly
 
when
 
operating
 
alongside
 
humans.
 
Moreover ,
 
his
 
game-theoretic
 
approach
 
to
 
modelling
 
human-robot
 
interaction
 
provides
 
a
 
principled
 
framework
 
for
 
addressing
 
the
 
multi-agent
 
challenges
 
I
 
seek
 
to
 
explore
 
during
 
doctoral
 
study .
 
I
 
am
 
also
 
drawn
 
to
 
Professor
 
Chi
 
Jin's
 
research
 
at
 
the
 
intersection
 
of
 
large
 
language
 
models,
 
reasoning,
 
and
 
multi-agent
 
systems.
 
His
 
work
 
on
 
multi-agent
 
generative
 
systems
 
(LLM
 
Economist)
 
and
 
minimax
 
language
 
agents
 
(PokéChamp)
 
provides
 
theoretical
 
frameworks
 
for
 

--- Page 3 ---

3
 
understanding
 
how
 
intelligent
 
agents
 
reason
 
and
 
interact,
 
addressing
 
questions
 
central
 
to
 
the
 
development
 
of
 
autonomous
 
systems
 
that
 
can
 
operate
 
alongside
 
humans
 
and
 
other
 
agents.
 
Moreover ,
 
his
 
continued
 
contributions
 
to
 
reinforcement
 
learning
 
theory ,
 
including
 
work
 
on
 
RLHF
 
complexity
 
and
 
provably
 
efficient
 
algorithms,
 
offer
 
principled
 
foundations
 
for
 
grounding
 
empirical
 
RL
 
methods
 
in
 
verifiable
 
guarantees,
 
particularly
 
for
 
settings
 
involving
 
sparse
 
feedback
 
and
 
safety-critical
 
decision-making.
 
Finally ,
 
Professor
 
Dhruv
 
Shah’ s
 
Princeton
 
Robotic
 
Intelligence
 
and
 
Systems
 
Lab
 
(PRISM)
 
offers
 
a
 
compelling
 
bridge
 
between
 
algorithmic
 
innovation
 
and
 
embodied
 
deployment.
 
I
 
am
 
particularly
 
drawn
 
to
 
PRISM's
 
full-stack
 
approach,
 
which
 
spans
 
algorithmic
 
design,
 
system
 
implementation,
 
and
 
empirical
 
validation.
 
Its
 
practice
 
of
 
drawing
 
inspiration
 
from
 
cognitive
 
science
 
to
 
inform
 
learning
 
systems
 
resonates
 
with
 
my
 
growing
 
interest
 
in
 
human-centred
 
AI
 
design,
 
an
 
interest
 
recently
 
reinforced
 
through
 
my
 
work
 
supporting
 
digital
 
psychological
 
assessment
 
tools.
 
Additionally ,
 
the
 
lab's
 
emphasis
 
on
 
multi-agent
 
and
 
human-robot
 
interaction
 
would
 
allow
 
me
 
to
 
explore
 
how
 
autonomous
 
agents
 
can
 
learn
 
to
 
operate
 
safely
 
and
 
effectively
 
in
 
human-populated
 
environments.
 
Together ,
 
the
 
work
 
of
 
these
 
faculty
 
members
 
reflects
 
the
 
interdisciplinary
 
balance
 
of
 
theory ,
 
safety ,
 
and
 
deployment
 
that
 
I
 
seek
 
in
 
my
 
doctoral
 
training.
 
A
 
PhD
 
is
 
the
 
essential
 
next
 
step
 
for
 
me
 
to
 
pursue
 
these
 
research
 
questions
 
with
 
the
 
depth
 
and
 
rigour
 
they
 
require.
 
My
 
primary
 
goal
 
is
 
an
 
academic
 
research
 
career ,
 
while
 
remaining
 
open
 
to
 
industry
 
research
 
labs
 
where
 
fundamental
 
RL
 
research
 
informs
 
deployment.
  
Princeton’ s
 
emphasis
 
on
 
human-centred
 
computing,
 
socially
 
impactful
 
research,
 
and
 
interdisciplinary
 
collaboration
 
provides
 
the
 
perfect
 
setting
 
for
 
me
 
to
 
grow
 
into
 
an
 
independent
 
researcher .
 
I
 
look
 
forward
 
to
 
contributing
 
my
 
technical
 
background,
 
research
 
curiosity ,
 
and
 
commitment
 
to
 
socially
 
responsible
 
AI
 
to
 
Princeton’ s
 
doctoral
 
community .
